text: A precise, orderly room. Comfortable and well maintained, not. fancy or trendy. Venetian blinds are drawn against t hot August sun. The room seems to be in repose. Suddenly face of DAISY WERTHAN appears, looking directly at us. Sh straightens the straw hat on her head. We realize we have been looking at a mirror image of the room. Daisy is seventy-two years old and apparently in excellen health. She wears a summer street dress, low-heeled white shoes and appropriate summer jewelry -- no makeup. She does not dwell on her mirror image, once the hat is adjusted. She reaches into a bureau drawer, takes out a p of white gloves, gets her pocket book from the closet and walks purposefully out of the room.

A. Daisy in the upstairs hall. B. Daisy walking down the carpeted steps. c. Daisy in the downstairs hall, which contains a commode with a 1930's telephone on it and various objets d'art. D. Daisy in the dining room, drapes closed against the ho sunlight. E. Daisy through the swinging door in the pantry. She moves briskly through the silent rooms. This is a wom who is never idle. Everything about her suggests energy a purpose. What we see of her house tells us that she is in comfortable circumstances. Bookshelves are evident in man the rooms. The furniture is overstuffed and/or mahogany.

A spacious, black-and-white tiled kitchen -- pre-W.W.I in dimension. The only sign of the times is a fairly modern range. ‘ IDELLA, black and close to Daisy's age, stands at the sin under the window, polishing silver with an old toothbrush She does not look up, or in any way acknowledge Daisy's entrance into the kitchen.  Daisy removes a shopping list from a cabinet drawer.
I'm gone to the market, Idelia.
Mmmmmm . Daisy heads out the door.

Bright hot sunlight, the yard shimmering in the morning h We can SEE the outside of the house now -- Georgian, buil the teens, comfortable, but not pretentious. Green canvas awnings protect the house from the sun. DAISY walks to the garage, a separate building, built for cars, but only holding one -- a shiny new 1948 Packard. S climbs into the car.

A. Daisy's gloved hand turns on the ignition. B. Her POV. Shifting the automatic gear into reverse. Cc. Her high-heeled foot pushing the accelerator. D. On the car, backing out of the garage and into the turnaround. E. On Daisy, gloved hands both clutching the wheel, back straight, not touching the seat. F. On the gear indicator, still in reverse. G. On Daisy's foot, gunning the accelerator. I. On the car, shooting backwards over an embankment, seemingly suspended in the air for a moment before it lan the roof of the garage next door (down the hill) causing garage to collapse, which, in turn, lands on the free-sta toolshed just adjacent to it, which also falls into piece seattering garden tools, etc., in all directions. The NOI is deafening. J. On Idella, looking out of the kitchen window in horror
Sweet Jesus! H. On a nursemaid and a toddler, coming out of the house door.
Daisy's severely damaged car sits in (on) what's left of garage. All is still.

Still in the car, still clutching the wheel with gloved h Her hat is crooked and her glasses are askew, but otherwi she is unhurt. She tests the door handle. It works. She pushes the door open, extracts her purse from the car and out.

What's left of Daisy's car rises in the air, ghost-like. PULL BACK reveals that the car is being hoisted by a tow and a gigantic chain and pulley operation. What's left of garage collapses like pick-up sticks. BOOLIE WERTHAN, Daisy's son, age 40, stands with a police and insurance agent in the yard. He wears a good summer business suit. A sizable part of the neighborhood, black servants, children, yard men, etc., stand silently at a respectful distance watching the proceedings.
He looks up the hill towards his mother's house.
Daisy is watching from her bedroom window, but moves quic out of the way when Boolie catches her eyes.
The pulley operation sets the remains of the car at rest. reverberations of this knock down what's left of the tool ON THE CROWD, watching silently.

Idella is sitting on a stool, eating fried chicken and po salad at the kitchen counter. Boolie is seated at the kit table, finishing off a plate of same. Each has a glass of tea and a paper napkin, but Idella's plate is a cracked remnant of an old pattern, her fork is from the dime stor and her tea is in a small mason jar. Boolie is eating off Daisy's everyday china and silver. Daisy is not in the ro but a THUMPING and CLUMPING 0.S. indicate that she is wit earshot. .
Mama!
No!
Mama!
No!
It's a miracle you're not laying in Emory Hospital -- or decked out at the funeral parlor. He rises from the table, and heads for

Daisy is in the pantry closet, having changed out of her street clothes into a house dress. She is kneeling on the floor by a large pickle crock, removing the lid, the rock holds down a plate, which, in turn, holds down the pickle their brine. She maneuvers the crock out of the closet an toward the pantry sink, waving away Boolie's efforts to h her. Once at the sink, she begins the operation of spearing pi that are already lined up by the sink and then ladling br into the jars and screwing on the jar tops. This operatio keeps her busy during the following scene. She spears the first pickle out of the crock and hands it to Boolie, who takes a bite.
The cucumbers are pretty this summer.
Look at you! You didn't even break your glasses.
It was the car's fault.
Mama, you had the car in the wrong gear.
I did not. (calls to Idella) Idella! You want a pickle with your lunch?
Not me.
Well, I'm putting up a jar for you to take home to William, you hear?
Yassum. Thank you. He love your pickles.
That's because he has more sense than you do.
You had the car in reverse instead of drive. The police report shows that.
You should have let me keep my LaSalle. It never ‘would have behaved this way.
Mama, cars don't behave. They are behaved upon. The fact is you, all by yourself, demolished that Packard.
Think what you want. I know the truth.
The truth is you just cost the insurance company twenty-seven hundred dollars. You are a terrible risk. Nobody is going to issue you a policy after this.
You're just saying that to be hateful.
Okay. Yes. Yes I am. I'm making it all up. Every insurance company in America is lined up out there in the driveway, waving their fountain pens and falling all over themselves to get you to sign on.
I love having you here for lunch, son, but if you're going to stand in my pantry and lie like a rug, well, I think it's time for you to go somewhere else.

Okay. I'd better get back to the office. Florine'll be having a fit if I don't come home on time tonight. DAISY . That's right. I forgot. Y'all are having dinner with the Ansleys tonight! I'm sure Florine bought another new dress. This is her idea of heaven on earth, isn't it?
What? .
Socializing with Episcopalians. BOOLIE . You're a doodle, Mama. I'11 stop by tomorrow evening.
How do you know I'll be here? I'm certainly not dependent on you for company.
Fine. I'll call first. But you know that we have got some real serious talking to do.
No.
Mama}!

(singing to end discussion) After the ball is over After the break of morn After the dancers leaving After the stars are gone Many a heart is aching If you could read them all -- As soon as she starts singing, Daisy, having finished her pickle business, turns on her heels and walks out of the pantry. We HEAR her SINGING continue and FADE as she clim the stairs and eventually shuts the door to her room. Boolie, having lost this round, picks up the largest maso of pickles to take home. ON HIS FACE: How do I handle this?
Daisy, wearing a light summer dressing gown, raises the blinds. Sunlight floods the room and she looks out of the window.
The garage stands empty, except for an old hand lawn mowe a few gardening tools at one side.
Daisy looks grim.
Daisy, now dressed, is on the phone.

(on the phone) Well, I need you now! I have to be at the beauty shop in half an hour! -.. No, I most certainly did not know you had to call a minimum of two hours ahead. I don't know why you call yourself a taxicab company if you can't provide taxicabs! ON IDELLA, standing in the dining room doorway with a dus rag in her hand, listening.
You call yo' son down at the plant, he sen’ somebody to carry you.
That won't be necessary. I'll cancel the appointment and fix my own hair.
Sometimes I think you ain't got the sense God gave a lemon! Daisy glares at her, but Idella, with inalienable right o side, returns the glare with a calm nod of her head and g off about her business.

Boolie enters from the kitchen. He is wearing brand new pressed jeans with the cuffs rolled up and a plaid short- Sleeved shirt and a bandanna around his neck. It looks wr on him. FLORINE, his wife, enters behind him. She is in her middl thirties, dark-haired, slim, very fashionable, carefully up. ‘Right now she is wearing a full denim skirt down to ankles (I think they called them circle skirts) and a pla blouse exactly matching Boolie's shirt. She is also weari gold jewelry that doesn't quite go with this outfit.
(calling upstairs) Mama? You there?
(also calling up) Hey, Mother Werthan! It's just us! ON DAISY, appearing at the landing, a book in her hand.
Why didn't you call?
We can't stay.
(sizing up the outfits) So I gather.
The Millers are giving a hayride for their anniversary.
I had these made. Doesn’t your baby look cute?
That's not exactly the word I'd pick. Boolie takes the book out of her hand.
I've been wanting to read this. He looks through it.
It's due back tomorrow. Want me to take it for you?
No thank you. I will go to the library on the streetcar. Boolie, getting angry, starts to say something, but Flori puts a hand on his arm to calm him.
Go on now. You don't want to _ keep the horses waiting. ON BOOLIE, exasperated.
Daisy, dressed in hat and gloves, and carrying the librar book, walks down the driveway towards the street.

Daisy, a young black maid, and a couple of others are wai at the bus stop. A City of Atlanta bus pulls up to the st A couple of passengers emerge from the rear door. The wai passengers enter the bus, Daisy first, in deference to he age, sex, and color.

Daisy puts in correct fare, squeezes into a seat between country woman and a high school girl.  10. The black maid, the last one aboard, goes to the back of bus, where there are black people standing and no seats. front of the bus has seats available.
The bus rattles off down the avenue.
A one-story brick building on a residential shopping stre Sign in front reads "Atlanta Public Library, Highland Ave
The checkout desk. The young LIBRARIAN is stamping Daisy' books.
I've got that Revolutionary War book you were asking about, Miz Werthan. I put it aside for you.
You're a sweet thing, Miss Jensen. The Librarian reaches under the counter and pulls out the book. It is enormous, more than a thousand pages.
Everybody's just crazy about it! Daisy eyes it dubiously as Librarian stamps it for her. -
Well, thank you very much. She turns from the desk and heads out the door, carrying huge book in the cradle of her arm.
The store is busy with shoppers. The PRODUCE MANAGER gree Daisy, who has her library book, her purse, and her glove the shopping cart.
How many peaches for you today, Miz Werthan?
Three, thank you.  il.
You're not gonna be gettin' any better ones the rest of the summer. Lemme give you a few more.
Just the three.

How about a nice watermelon? Daisy shakes her head "no," puts the paper sack of peache into her cart, which already contains one bar of soap, on lamb chop, and a can of peas. She walks toward the checko counter.

Across the street from where Daisy started out. The bus r INTO VIEW, the doors open and Daisy emerges, carrying her purse, the big library book, and a medium-size grocery st bag. She walks briskly down the street.
Daisy walking up the driveway, not quite so briskly, lugg her parcels. CLOSEUP OF HER FACE. JAW SET.

A smallish turn-of-the-century brick factory built near t railroad tracks. A company truck is backed up to a loadin platform. Several black men are involved in loading large cartons of printed material into the truck. A sleek, late model sedan is parked in the space marked "Reserved for M Werthan." A couple of less fancy cars are parked in other reserved spots. A mid-week, mid-morning, business-as-usua ay. .

Somebody (Florine) has tried to furnish this office well. contains a good leather couch, a couple of English-hunt-c type engravings and an expensive mahogany desk. A large V magazine~-style photograph of Florine in a fancy hat is p prominently. Also there are company picnic photographs, Boolie's Yale diploma, a Bacharach-type photograph of his father, etc. All of the above does not quite hide the fac that this room is part of an old factory. The walls are patchy, the windows are old, and the venetian blinds are grubby and sagging.  12. Boolie is at the desk and on the phone. During his phone conversation a SHARP BELL is HEARD O.S. It RINGS intermittently. He looks up, annoyed, then concerned, but continues doing his business.

Well, I.W., you know as well as I do that The Werthan Company isn't the only printing company in Atlanta. If you want to get other bids... oh, you did. Well... that's what Ideal bid, huh?... Okay. You ever do business with Ideal before? MISS MCCLATCHEY, his secretary, all business and about 30 appears at the door. She seems distressed. He raises his hand, palm up, telling her to wait.
It's important, Mr. Werthan.
(on the phone) Can you have lunch with me tomorrow? Herrens all right? Yes. Unh hunh. ‘Twelve thirty. Love to Peggy and the children. (to Miss McClatchey) What's wrong?
Oscar's stuck in the freight elevator.
Damn that thing! He gets up, leaves his office. She follows.

A. A CORRIDOR. Boolie, followed by McClatchey, hurries do a corridor. Glass-partitioned cubbyhole offices (3 or 4) men in shirtsleeves at desks, on phones, etc. B. END OF THE CORRIDOR. Boolie opens a large metal double door and they proceed to C. THE FACTORY. An enormous room, full of printing presse in full swing. Various workers are operating the machines stacking material onto hand trucks, etc. The room is lit mostly by the skylighted roof. Boolie and McClatchey hurr through to  13. D. THE FREIGHT ELEVATOR. It is about four feet above the ground. The old corrugated tin door is open and we SEE a of shoes and legs up to the knees.
Oscar?
Yassuh. Here I am.
You all right?
Nawsuh. I'm stuck.
I know. Fiddle with the lever.
It all fiddled out. I done everythin' I know how.
Oh, Jesus! Call Bell Elevator, Miss McClatchey.
I already did. They're backed up. But they’1l be here around one.
One! Did you tell them it's an emergency? :
You don't have to holler at me, Mr. Werthan. I didn't break the elevator. A small crowd of workers has gathered behind Boolie. This an event.
You got that stuff for Davison Paxon in there, Oscar?
Wrapped and ready to go.
I told them they'd have it yesterday. Call Bell back! McClatchey goes off to the phone.  14.

Oscar! Oscar? Boolie turns to look and so does the CAMERA. We SEE a SIXTYISH BLACK MAN, neat, but dressed in a shiny suit, a frayed old white-on-white shirt and a sad-looking tie. Clearly somebody down on his luck.
You,hear me, Oscar?
I hear you.
Is there a little doo-hickey up yonder where the gate suppose to Close? Stickin' down a little?
Wait a minute... Yeah. Unh hunh. It right here.
Well, reach up and mash on it... Mash it up till it catch.
I done it. Now what?

Well, just work the lever. A LOUD THUMP, A WHIRR OF MOTOR, and OSCAR, a black man in forties, dressed in a porter's uniform, appears at ground level in the elevator, stacks of printed material behind A light round of APPLAUSE, workers immediately start pack the material onto hand trucks and moving it out.
(to the Old Man) Excuse me, do you work here?
Nawsah, this Hoke.
Pleased to see you, suh...
(at a loss) Oh. Well, thank you. How did you know about the elevator?  15.
I used to drive for the Avondale Dairy and they have a old sorry elevator worse than dishyah.
Don' you remember? Hoke the one I tole you about.
Oh. Of course. Well, come on back with me to my office. Hoke, is it?
Hoke Coleburn, suh. The following takes place. as they walk back to Boolie's office.
You're not with the Avondale Dairy any more?
Nosuh. They lay me off back befo' las' November.
*Long time.

Well, Mist' Werthan, you try bein' me and lookin' for work. They hirin' young if they hirin' colored and they ain' even hirin' much young seem like. They walk in silence for a bit. Boolie is clearly not ver interested.
Mist’ Werthan? Y'all people Jewish, ain't you? Boolie stops and turns around.
Yes we are. Why do you ask?
Well, suh, I'd druther drive for Jews. People always talkin' ‘bout they Stingy and they cheap, but don' say none of that ‘round me.  16.
Good to know you feel that way.

Yassah. One time I workin’ for this woman over near Little Five Points. What was that woman's name? I forget. Anyway, she president of the Ladies Auxiliary over yonder to the Ponce de Leon Baptist Church and seem like she always bringin' up God and Jesus and do unto others. You know what I'm talkin' 'bout?
I don't think so.

Well, one day, Mist' Werthan, one day that woman say to me, she say, "Hoke, come on back in the back wid' me. I got something for you." And we go on back yonder and Lawd have mercy, she have all these old shirts and collars be on the bed, and she say, "Ain't they nice? They b'long to my Daddy befo' he pass, and we fixin' to sell ‘em to you for twenty-five cent apiece."
What was her name?

Thass what I'm askin' myself. What was that woman's name? They have reached BOOLIE'S OFFICE now. Miss McClatchey is typing at her desk. Boolie proceeds to his desk and start signing papers. Hoke follows, talking a blue streak.
Anyway, them's the people callin' Jews cheap. So I say, "Yassum, I think about it" and I get me another job as fas' as I can.
Where was that?
Mist' Harold Stone, another Jewish gentleman jes' like you. Judge, live over yonder on Liillwater Road.  17.
(looks up, interested) I knew Judge Stone.
You doan' say! He done give me this here suit when he finish with it. An' this necktie, too!
You drove for Judge Stone?

Seven years to the day, nearabout. An' I be there still if he din' up and die, and Miz Stone decide to close up the house and move to her people in Savannah. And she say, "Come on down to Savannah wid me, Hoke." ‘Cause my wife dead by then, and I say, "No thank you." I din' want to leave my granbabies and I don' get along with that low-class Geechee trash they got down there.
Judge Stone was a friend of my father's.
You doan' mean! Oscar say you need a driver for yo' family. What I be doin'? Runnin’ yo' children to school and yo' wife to the beauty parlor and like dat?
I don't have any children. But tell me --
Tha's a shame. My daughter bes' thing ever happen to me. But you young yet. I wouldn't worry none.
I won't. Thank you. Hoke, what I'm looking for is somebody to drive my mother around.
Excuse me for asking, but how com’ she ain' hire for herself?  18.
Well, it's a difficult situation.
Mmmm Hmmm. She done gone 'roun' the bend a little? That'll happen when they get on.
Oh no. Nothing like that. It just isn't safe for her to drive any more. I'll be frank with you. I'ma little desperate.

I know what you mean 'bout dat. Once I outta work, my wife say to me, "Oooh, Hoke, you ain' gon' get noun ‘nother job." And I say, "What you talkin' 'bout, woman?" And the very next week I go to work for that woman in Little Five Points. Cahill! Mrs. Prances Cahill. And then I got to Judge Stone and they the reason I happy to hear you Jews.

Hoke, I want you to understand, my mother is a little high-strung. She doesn't want anybody driving her. But the fact is you'd be working for me. She can say anything she likes but she can't fire you. You understand?

Sho' I do. Don' you worry none about it. I hold on no matter what way she run me. When I nothin' but a little boy down there on the farm above Macon where I come from, I use to wrastle hogs to the ground at killin’ time. And ain' no hog got away from me yet.
How does twenty dollars a week sound?
Soun' like you done hire yo' Mama a chauffeur. Boolie smiles with relief. ON HOKE, pleased, but not quite sure what he's gotten him into.  19.
A late model sedan drives up the driveway. Boolie driving Hoke in the seat beside him. Both look apprehensive. They get out of the car and walk toward the back door.
Daisy seen in the window watching the arrival. She is not smiling.

The front hall. Dim light in contrast to the sun outside. Idella is going over the floor with a carpet sweeper. She singing a hymn ("Are You Washed in the Blood of the Lamb" mostly to herself. Boolie comes into the hall, Hoke behind him.
How are you, Idella?
Livin'.
Where's that vacuum cleaner I brought over here?
In the closet.
(to Hoke) She won't touch it.
I would if it din' give me a shock every time I go near it.
It works for me.
Good. You clean up. I go down and run yo' office. Hoke laughs. Idella shoots him a look.
Where's Mama?
Up yonder.  20.
I guess you know who this is.
Mmmm Hmmm. She goes back to her carpet sweeping.
I'll be right back, Hoke. He heads up the steps.
(to Hoke) I wouldn't be in your shoes if the Sweet Lawd Jesus come down and ask me hisself! ON HOKE, sizing up the situation.
Boolie knocks on Daisy's closed bedroom door.
Mama?
Come in.
Daisy is seated at a small desk, checkbook open, paying b She does not rise when Boolie enters. He bends over and t to kiss her cheek, but she pulls away.
Good morning, Mama. No answer. She continues paying bills.
All I'm asking is for you to come and say hello.

Now you listen here. Unless they rewrote the Constitution and didn't tell me, I still have rights. And one of my rights is to invite who I want -- not who you want -- into my house. You do accept the fact that this is my house?  21.
Well, of course I do, Mama, but --

What I do not want -- and absolutely will not have is some -- some chauffeur sitting in my kitchen, gobbling up my food, running up my Phone bill. Oh, I hate all that in My house. On Forsyth Street we couldn't afford them and we did for ourselves. That's still the best way if you ask me.
Them? Afford them? You sound like Governor Talmadge.
Why, Boolie! What a thing to say! I'm not prejudiced! Aren't you ashamed.
I got to get back to the plant. You might as well try to make the best of this, Mama. He leaves, shitting the door. ON DAISY'S FACE, jaw set.
Hoke, having removed his jacket, and neatly rolled up his shirt sleeves, .is looking through the broom closet. Bool comes into the kitchen.
She'll be down in a while.
I ain' studyin' her, Mist' Werthan. You ain' got to concern yourself. Look like ain' nobody dusted nary a light bulb 'roun' here in fifty years! Where y'all keep the stepladder?
In the pantry closet, I think. Good luck.
You sayin' something now!  22. Boolie smiles, goes out the back door.
Hoke is standing on the stepladder, dusting the lightbulb the ceiling fixture. Daisy comes into the room.
Here! What do you think you're doing?
Dustin' yo' bulbs, Miz Daisy.
That's the silliest thing I ever saw in my life. Who cares if light bulbs are dusty? Get down from there.
Yassum.
And put that ladder away before somebody trips on it.
Late afternoon sunlight slants into the room. Idella is rolling out biscuit dough. Hoke is sitting on a stool nea
I knew a Miss Idella once, down there above Macon.
Doan' say.

You talkin' 'bout sing! I mean that woman had lungs! She'd a been a whole church choir by herseff if they'd a let her. And fat, too! She about the size of that stove yonder. Idella laughs. Daisy comes into the kitchen.
Don't talk to Idella. She has work to do.
Yassum.  23.

Hoke is standing on the landing studying the framed pictu on the wall. CLOSEUP framed photo turn-of-the-century fifth grade clas teacher, young Daisy, in Gibson Girl blouse. Daisy comes into the hall from her bedroom.
What are you doing there?
I love a house with pictures. Make a home. Dishere you, ain't it?
Yes.
Look like you bin a teacher or something.
I don't want you nosing through my things. She goes back into her room.
Idella is wearing her street.clothes and carrying a shopp bag. Hoke has on his jacket, and carries his chauffeur's in his hand.
(calling up the stairs) I'm gone, Miz Daisy.
All right, Idella. See you tomorrow.
(also calling upstairs) I'm gone too, Miz Daisy.
Good! Idella and Hoke exchange looks and head out the door.  24.
The side of the house. Hoke is kneeling down examining a of flowers. He has a trowel in his hand. Daisy appears in a first floor window.
Looks like yo' zeenias use a little tendin' to.
You leave my flower bed alone.
Yassum but you be sorry somebody doan get after them weeds. Daisy shuts the windows and disappears.

Daisy and Idella, wearing aprons, stand at the counter. D is making chili sauce. Idella is washing up after her. Peeled tomatoes, onions, etc., wait on the counter. At th moment she is boiling mason jars in a huge kettle. Hoke c in from the back porch.

You know, Miz Daisy, you got a nice place back beyond the garage ain't doin' nothin' but sittin' there. I could put you some butterbeans and some tomatoes and even some Irish potatoes could we get someone with good eyes.
If I want a vegetable garden I'll plant it for myself.
Well, anything else I kin do fo' you?
Go back where you belong...
Yassum. I b'long here. Mist’ Werthan expec' me to stay 'till five o'clock. Lemme carry you somewhere in de car.
No thank you.  25. She forks a boiling jar out of the cauldron. End of conversation. She gives a small smile of triumph to Idell
The flowerbed. Daisy, wearing a gardening hat, is on her knees weeding the flowerbed. Hoke walks up the driveway a sees her.
Mornin' Miz Daisy.
Good morning.
Them zeenias lookin' lot better. No answer.
Right cool in the night, wadn' it?
I wouldn't know. I was asleep.
Yassum. What yo' plans for today?
That's my business.
You right about dat. I find somethin' to do. He goes off toward the garage. She looks after him.
A brand new Oldsmobile sedan is parked in the garage. Hok goes into the garage and is getting into the car. Daisy c up behind him.
What are you doing?
Fixin' to back de car out.
Why? I'm not going anywhere.  26.
Nome, I know dat, but I brung thisshyeah from home. He pulls a small soft cloth from his coat.
Give the car a good wipe off.
What for? It isn't dirty. It's never even been out of the garage.
You tellin' me!
I don't want you touching my car. You understand? He reluctantly gets out of the car.
Yassum. I reckon I jes' set in the kitchen 'till five o'clock.
That's your affair. Hoke goes off towards the back door, a sad stoop to his shoulders. Daisy watches him with some satisfaction. Then she goes back to attack her flowerbed.
Very sunny. Daisy sits on one of the porch chairs, readin the morning paper. Idella enters from the house.
We runnin’ outta coffee and Dutch cleanser.
We are? IDELLA . Yassum and we low on silver polish, too.
I know... I'm fixin' to go to the Piggly Wiggly on the trolley. Hoke emerges from the house where he has been listening.  27.
Now, Miz Daisy, how come you doan let me carry you?

No, thank you. She puts the paper down and walks through the LIVING ROOM to the FRONT HALL where her straw hat sits on the hall commode. has followed her and they talk as she pins her hat on her and gathers her purse and gloves. Idella, in b.g., is straightening the living room.
Ain' that what Mist’ Werthan done hire me for?
That's his problem.
All right den. I find somethin’ to do.
You leave my things alone! (calls to the living room) I'm gone to the market, Idella!
Yassum. Daisy marches out the front door.
Bright, hot sunlight. Daisy walking briskly toward the driveway, Hoke following.

You know, it seem a downright shame. That fine Oldsmobile settin' out there in the garage. Ain' move a inch from when Mist' Werthan rode it over here from Mitchell Motors. Only got nineteen miles on it. Seem like that insurance company done give you a whole new car for nothin’.
That's your opinion.  28.

Yassum. And my other opinion is a fine rich Jewish lady like you doan b'long draggin' up the steps of no bus luggin’ no grocery sto' bags. I come along and carry them fo' you. Daisy stops walking and turns to have it out.
I don't need you. I don't want you. And I don't like you saying I'm rich.
I won' say it no more then.

Is that what you and Idella talk about in the kitchen? Oh, I hate all this! I hate being discussed behind my back in my own house! I was born on Forsyth Street and believe you me I know the value of a penny. My brother, Manny, brought home a white cat one day and Papa said we couldn't keep it because we couldn't afford to feed it. My sisters saved up money so I could go . to school and be a teacher. We didn't have anything!

For how much?
Dat for him arid me to know. They are inspecting the new car now. RED MITCHELL himself all smiles, having made two sales, comes out to join them
Well, hey, Boolie! You got a gem here. You got that payment for me, Hoke?
Sho' do...
We'll be right in, Red. Mitchell heads back towards the building. Boolie walks Ho .little ways away.
For God's sake! Why didn't you just buy it right from Mama? You'd have saved money.  58.

Yo' Mama in my bizness enough as it is. I ain' studyin' makin' no monthly car payments to her. Dis here mine the regular way. The two cars are side-by-side in the sun, the one gleamin phe other also glowing, but with age. Boolie pats the old ondly.
It's a good car, all right. I guess nobody knows that better than you.
Bes' ever come off the line. And dis new one, Miz Daisy doan take to it, I let her ride in disheah now an' again.
Mighty nice of you.
Well, we all doin' what we can.

Boolie, holding the keys to the new car and his copy of t papers, shakes hands with Red Mitchell at the door. Hoke follows him out the door, holding his own set of papers. Mitchell waves and goes back inside. Boolie lights a cigarette.
You want to drive the new one home?
No suh.
Why the hell not?
‘Cause I doan want you gettin’ them nasty ashes all over my 'polstry.

ON IDELLA'S HANDS lifting fried chicken out of a sputteri skillet and onto waiting paper towels. PULL BACK to revea Idella herself, probably in her eighties now, and looking bit worn. The kitchen counter holds hardboiled egg whites waiting to be stuffed, carrot sticks, and other indicatio picnic-making in progress.  59. Golden afternoon sun streams into the room, which now con a fifties refrigerator, a new dinette and chairs, and a c wall calendar, which reads "June, 1957." Daisy comes into the kitchen. Daisy starts
That's not enough chicken.
How much you and Hoke plannin' to eat?
I like to give them leftovers when I get there.
You will, less you make a pig of yo'seff.
Did you put mustard in those eggs?
I always put mustard in my stuffed eggs.
Spicy things make me sick.
You go on upstairs and see ‘bout your packing. I leave everything ready to put in the car in the morning. out of the kitchen, but remembers something.
Don't put the peaches in the icebox. I hate cold peaches. .
Yassum. Daisy leaves, and Idella goes on with the preparations, muttering to She spears a herself. .
Act like I ain' never made a picnic in my life. piece of chicken vehemently.  60.

Daisy's bedroom has undergone the usual changes in the ni so years since we've seen it. A late model (middle fiftie bedside radio has replaced the large pre-war one. The wallpaper is different, though it looks very much like it predecessor. The room is still well kept. Daisy is dresse in traveling clothes. She is about eighty now, but still good health. She moves a bit more carefully. It is early morning. The sun is recently up. A large, old fashioned suitcase sits open on one of the twin beds. It just about full. Everything is wrapped carefully in layer tissue paper. Daisy has been packing it for days, and the is just about complete. She looks out of her front window towards the street and frowns. She checks her wristwatch. The street again. And she makes a decision. Chin set resolutely, she slams the suitcase shut and snaps the various locks closed. Another check to the street. She lifts the suitcase off the bed. is almost too heavy for her.

head_text.subj: A SERIES OF SHOTS OF DAISY WITH THE SUITCASE

text: A. Struggling out of her bedroom door. B. Bumping down the hall steps. Cc. Going through the dining room. D. Battling with the swinging door into the pantry. E. Emerging into the back yard and half-dragging it acros the driveway.

location: DAISY'S HOUSE / THE DRIVEWAY AND GARAGE

text: A beautiful, soft, early summer morning. Birds singing, Daisy's garden is in gentle bloom. All in contrast to Dai rising irritation. She looks toward the street, pushes a stray wisp of hair back under its net and goes resolutely into the house.

Daisy enters the kitchen. A shoebox sits open on the tabl It contains various components of the picnic lunch, all carefully wrapped in waxed paper. Daisy opens the refrigerator, gets a couple more wrapped packages and put them in the shoebox. She closes the box and wraps it with rubber band, irritation still mounting. She gathers it, a good-sized, fancily-wrapped gift box, and heads out the b door again.
Daisy has placed the suitcase at the rear We HEAR the SOUND of head of the driveway Hoke gets out of the 61.

gift box and the lunch box on top of the of the garage by the trunk of the car. a CAR pulling up. We FOLLOW HER to the and we SEE Hoke's car pulling up. car, goes around to the trunk and removes his own small suitcase. His car is the same Oldsmobile, a worse for wear now, but still kept well. The Cadillac, al is now a couple of years old and has lost its new car shi
It's three after seven! Yassum. fifteen
You say we leavin' at to eight.
At the latest, I said.
Now what bizness you got, draggin' disheah out de house by yoseff?
Who was here to help me?
Miz Daisy, it doan take mo'n five minutes to load up de trunk of dis car. You fixin' to break both yo' arms and yo'legs Atlanta. too fo' we even get outta You takin' on too much.
I hate doing things at the last minute.
What you talkin’ ‘bout? You ready to go fo’ the las' week and a half! He picks up the present.
Don't touch that.
Ain' it wrap pretty! Dat Mist' Walter's present?  62.

Yes. It's fragile. I'11 hold it on the seat with me. Hoke is loading the trunk under Daisy's careful supervisi Boolie's car pulls up the driveway. Boolie, dressed ina business suit and carrying a small wrapped gift, gets out his car and kisses his mother's cheek.
Well, you nearly missed us!
T thought you were leaving at quarter of.
She takin' on.
Be still.
Florine sent this for Uncle Walter. r He holds out the gift. Daisy recoils from it.
Well, it's not a snake, Mama. I think it's note paper.
How appropriate. Uncle Walter can't see!
Maybe it's soap.
How nice that you show such an interest in your uncle's ninetieth birthday.
Don't start up, Mama. I cannot go to Mobile with you. I have to go to New York tonight for the convention.
The convention starts Monday. And I know what else I know.  63.
Just leave Florine out of it. She wrote away for those tickets eight Months ago.
I'm sure "My Fair Lady" is more important than your own flesh and blood.
Mama!
Those Christians will be mighty impressed.

I can't talk to you when you're like this. Daisy has gotten herself into the car. The two gifts and lunch and her purse and her map are on the seat beside. S sits straight in the seat, ready to travel.
They expect us for a late supper in Mobile. :
You'll be there. I've got to talk to Hoke a minute. He takes Hoke out of Daisy's hearing.
I know they'll fix crab. All that trouble.
(to Hoke) I don't know how you're going to Stand all day in the car.
She doan mean nothin'. She jes' worked up.
Here's fifty dollars in case you run into trouble. Don't show it to Mama. You've got your map.  64.
She got it in wid her. Study ever’ inch of the way.
I'll be at the Ambassador Hotel in New York. On Park Avenue.
It's seven-sixteen.
You ought to have a job on the radio announcing the time.
I want to miss rush hour.
Congratulate Uncle Walter for me. And kiss everybody in Mobile. Hoke gets in the car and starts up the engine.
Did you have the air condition checked? I told you to have the air condition checked.
Yassum I had the air condition checked but I don't know what for. You doan never ‘low me to turn it on.
Hush up. The car moves out of the garage, turns around and heads d the driveway. Boolie stands at the head of the driveway, waving.
Goodbye! Good luck! (to himself) Good God!

‘1. DAISY'S CAR heading down the quiet suburban street. 2. DAISY'S CAR in traffic on a main thoroughfare. 3. DAISY'S CAR on a highway.  65. 4. INT. DAISY'S CAR. Daisy reading the map and telling Ho which numbered road to follow. 5. DAISY'S CAR on a highway, city skyline in the b.g. 6. DAISY'S CAR on a two-lane country road, mid-morning no 7. INT. DAISY'S CAR. Daisy, relaxed somewhat in her seat, window open, enjoying the countryside. Hoke, jacket remov doing same in front seat.

Daisy's car is pulled off to the side of a two-lane black road, somewhere near the Georgia/Alabama border. It is a beautiful summer day, not especially hot. Daisy and Hoke in the process of eating the lunch packed in the shoebox, fried chicken, stuffed eggs, etc. Daisy is sitting in her seat with the car door open. Hoke stands by the car, usin the hood as an outdoor table. The mood is very relaxed.
Idella stuff eggs good.
You stuff yourself good. They eat in peaceful silence. DAISY (CONT'D) . I was thinking about the first time I ever went to Mobile. It was Walter's wedding. 1888.
1888! You weren't nothing but a little child!

I was twelve. We went on the train. And I was so excited. I'd never been in a wedding party and I'd never seen the ocean. Papa said it was the Gulf of Mexico and not the ocean, but it was all the same to me. I remember we were at a picnic somewhere -- somebody must have taken us bathing -- and I asked Papa if it was all right to dip my hand in the water. He laughed because I was so timid. And then I tasted the salt water on my fingers. Isn't it silly to remember that?  66.
No sillier than most of what folks remember. A STATE PATROL CAR pulls up alongside the parked car. TWO TROOPERS in uniform are in the front seat.
(to Hoke) Hey, boy! Hoke looks at him evenly.
What do you think you're doing with this car?
(also calm but angry) This is my car, officer. The Trooper gets out of the patrol car and walks over.
Yes, ma'am. Can I see the registration, please. (to Hoke) And your license, boy. Hoke produces both the registration from the glove compar and the license from his wallet. The Trooper studies both
(to Daisy) What's this name? Wetheran?
Werthan.
Werthan. Never heard that one before. What kind of a name is that?
It's of German derivation.
German, hunh? Coulda fooled me. I thought it was a Jew name. The other Trooper smirks in the patrol car. The First Tro tips his hat to Daisy and they drive away.  67.

Daisy's car, traveling, passes an old pickup, headed the way. The pickup, a white farmer family, parents, grandpar and children, dressed in overalls and simple country clot CLOSEUP OF HUSBAND AND WIFE exchanging silent glance at t sight of Daisy's chauffeur-driven car.
Marker says "Entering Alabama." Daisy's car travels by.
Deep country, cotton fields, an occasional snack, a less occasional car.
You talkin' ‘bout first time before. I tell you 'bout the first time I ever leave the state of Georgia?
When was that?
A few minutes back.
Go on!

Thass right. First time. My daughter, she married to a Pullman porter on the N.C. & St. L., you know, and she all the time goin' -- Detroit, New York, St. Louis -- talkin' 'bout snow up aroun' her waist and ridin' in de subway car and I say, "Well, that very nice, Tommie Lee, but I jes' doan feel the need." So dis it, Miz Daisy, and I got to tell you, Alabama ain’ lookin' like much so far.
It's nicer the other side of Montgomery.
If you say so. Pass me up one of them peaches, please ma'am.  68. She reaches into the shoebox. A road sign catches her eye
Oh my God!
What happen?
That sign said Phenix City -- thirty miles. We're not supposed to go to Phenix City. We're going the wrong way! Oh my God!
Maybe you done read it wrong.
I didn't. Stop the car! Stop the car!
Hoke swerves off the road, next to a field. The mood is tense, in contrast to the peaceful lunch stop.
Daisy, very agitated, wrestles with the map on her lap.
Here! Here! You took the wrong turn at Opelika. He takes the map and reads it.
You took it wid me. And you readin’ the map!
I was getting the lunch. Go on back. Oh my God!
It ain' been thirty minutes since we turn.
I'm such a fool! I didn't have any business coming in the car by myself with just you. Boolie made me! I should have come on the train. I'd be safe there. I just should have come on the train.  69.
Yassum. You sho' shouldda'.

1. DAISY'S CAR pulling out into the road. 2. DAISY'S CAR traveling through an Alabama country town, square, a courthouse, white people, black people clustere separately on benches, etc., watching the fine car pass through, an event. 3. INT. CAR. No conversation. It's getting hot and sticky Late afternoon now. 4. EXT. COUNTRY GAS STATION - NEAR DUSK. Daisy's car pull up to the pump. A man in overalls fills the tank. Daisy emerges from the ladies' room, a distasteful look on her regarding the condition inside. 5. EXT. COUNTRY ROAD - DARK. Daisy's car still heading towards Mobile.
Hoke driving, Daisy in her seat, both somewhat slumped. T are tired. It's a humid, dark night. Large moths and smal insects fly at the windshield.
They fixed crab for me! Minnie always fixes crab! They go to so much trouble! It's all ruined by now! Oh Lord!
We got to pull over, Miz Daisy.
Is something wrong with the car?
Nome. I got to be'xcused.
What?
I got to make water.
You should have thought of that back at the Standard Oil station.  70.
Colored cain' use the toilet at no Standard Oil. You know dat.
Well, there's no time to stop. We'll be in Mobile soon. You can wait.
Yassum. {a beat) Nome.
Daisy's car pulls abruptly to the side of the road. INT. CAR - SAME TIME ‘
I told you to wait!
Yassum. I hear you. How you think I feel havin' to ax you when can I make my water like I some damn dog?
Why, Hoke! I'd be ashamed!

I ain' no dog and.I ain' no chile and I ain' just a back of the neck you look at while you going wherever you want to go. I aman, nearly seventy- two years old, and I know when my bladder full and I gettin' out dis car and goin' off down the road like I got to do. And I'm takin' the car key dis time. And that's the end of it! He gets out of the car, shutting the door sharply behind ON DAISY, sitting straight in her seat, lips pursed. Dark country night silence. A DOG BARKS in the distance. She rolls down the wiridow.
Hoke! She waits a second, then calls again, less angrily.
Hoke!  71. No answer. Silence. Darkness. COUNTRY SOUNDS. She is becoming frightened.
Hoke! She starts to get out of the car, when suddenly a man app in the shadowy dark. She is frightened for a moment, but realizes it is Hoke come back.
You all right in there, Miz Daisy? Her face floods with relief, but not for long. Soon she i her old snappish self.
Of course I am!

A standard twin-bedded double room. Nicely furnished, but very large. A room air conditioner hums away. White gauzy curtains billow in front of it. Open suitcases on the lug rack and bureau. Boolie, wearing boxer shorts, undershirt, long socks and garters, is stretched out on one of the beds, talking on telephone, which sits on a table between the beds. During his conversation, Florine emerges from the bathroo She is dressed in her best evening outfit -- a killer of summer city dress (a sack dress? one with a balloon skirt whatever Kay Kendall would have worn in 1957).

Yes. I'm calling Mobile, Alabama. Adams 4-7893. That's Adams. I don't know what digits. Wait a minute. 23. 234-7893. Person to person. Mr. Walter Woolf. No, wait, Operator. Make that station to station. (to Florine) It'll take forever to get Uncle Walter to the phone. Florine, intent on her mirror image, shrugs.
(on the phone) Yeah. Hey! Is this Slick? Hey, Slick! It's Boolie! Unh hunh. Congratulations on your Dad's big day.  72.

location: UNCLE WALTER'S HOUSE / THE LIVING ROOM

text: An unpretentious, comfortable Mobile living room -- not n as well-to-do as Daisy's house in Atlanta. SLICK, Uncle Walter's son, is a sixtyish small man, dressed in short-s white shirt, no tie, etc. He is talking on the phone with Boolie. In the b.g. are UNCLE WALTER, blind and ninety, b the possessor of great vitality. He happens to strongly resemble his sister, Daisy. He is ensconced in his favori living room chair, a pile of wrapped presents, Daisy's included, on a table nearby. He is surrounded by various children, grandchildren and relatives, including Daisy an Slightly older sister, NONIE. Slick is having trouble hearing Boolie over the b.g. NOIS
Well, thank you. Thank you, Boolie. (he beckons to Daisy) Aunt Daisy, it's Boolie calling.
A prim smile. She's glad her son is doing the right thing She leaves the relatives and takes the phone from Slick.
Hello. Hey, son. Uncle Walter appreciates your call. I don't think he can come to the phone.
(on phone) Fine. How is Hoke? —

What do you mean? How should he be? Uncle Walter's daughter emerges from the kitchen bearing large iced angel food cake, aglow with candles. An excite hush falls over the family and the singing of "Happy Birt starts.

I have to hang up, Boolie. I'll tell him. Yes, we will. All right. You, too. Bye. The cake procession and the singing continue.  73. ON UNCLE WALTER, his blind, pink face lit by the glow of ninety candles. ON DAISY, also lit by the candles, her face soft with lov pride for the occasion. She looks across the room.

Hoke standing by the kitchen door with MINNIE and a coupl other family servants. Hoke nods gravely at Daisy, acknowledging the importance of the moment. ON DAISY. She nods imperceptibly, but gratefully, back at Hoke, still lit by the candles. ON UNCLE WALTER, guided by Slick, leans over to blow the candles out.
The same exterior, but with a few changes. A very large billboard in front of the factory entrance reads:

The rest of the old Werthan plant and the projected moder addition at the rear. The Cadillac that was driven to Mobile pulls into an empt space. It is older now and a little worse for wear, but i kept well. It now belongs to Hoke. He emerges from the ca a bit greyer, but spry. He is up in his seventies. He wav to some men on the loading dock, who wave back. He heads the building.

location: THE WERTHAN COMPANY / THE RECEPTION AREA

text: The receptionist waves Hoke in and he proceeds down the corridor to

where she is seated, typing letters. Boolie's voice is HE on the DICTAPHONE machine by her side. She types as fast he talks. When she sees Hoke she smiles, turns off her machine. : MCCLATCHEY . Well, good morning to you.
Can I see him?
He's out there with the construction. Best toy he ever had.  74.

I know that's the truth. ‘He walks back down the hall and through the FACTORY, which looks pretty much as it did fourteen years before, past the same old FREIGHT ELEVATOR with the same old corrugated tin door. Oscar, older now, is unloading full hand carts.
Hey, my man!
They ain' give you a new elevator yet?
You don't see one, do you?
Well all right. He proceeds through the factory and out a rear door.

The early stages of construction. Concrete poured on firs floor and I-beams being put in place. Boolie, wearing har hat and expensive suit, talking to CONSTRUCTION WORKERS. Boolie is a bit paunchier and balder.
Eddie, are you telling me you're going over already?
No suh, Mist' Werthan. I'm just sayin' be prepared, if you git my meanin'.
I'm prepared to spend exactly what's in the contract and not one dime more.
I hear you. Boolie sees Hoke. He moves away from the construction gro
(to a worker as Boolie moves away) They don't call 'em Jews for nothing.  75. The other man snickers.
(to Hoke) Isn't it your day off? To what do I owe this honor?
Seein' ‘bout things in the neighborhood.
Well, let me show you around. They move around to a
(pointing up at empty air) Right there's gonna be my office. One hell of a view.
Isn't that something?
You don't seem real interested. .
We got to talk, Mr. Werthan.
What is it?
It Mist' Sinclair Harris.
My cousin Sinclair?
His wife.
Jeanette? :
The one talk funny.
She’s from Canton, Ohio.  76.
Yassuh. She tryin' to hire me.
What?

‘She phone when she know Miz Daisy be out and she say, "How are they treating you, Hoke?" You know how she soun', like her nose stuff up. And I say, "Fine, Miz Harris," and she say, "Well, if you lookin' for a change, you know where to call."
I'll be damned!
I thought you want to know ‘bout it.
I'll be God damned!
Ain' she a mess? (a pause) She say name yo sal'ry.
I see. And did you?
Did I what?
Name your salary.
Now, what you think I am? I ain' studyin' workin' for no trashy somethin' like her.
But she got you to thinkin', didn't she? :
You might could say dat.
Come on back in my office. They head back inside the factory.  77.

The same space as before, but serious redecoration has occurred. It is now furnished with the latest blonde maho desk, coffee table, side piece, etc. The wall-to-wall carpeting and drapes are new, too. And there is a new fas photo of Florine placed prominently. She has Mamie Eisenh bangs in it. Boolie sits at his desk, puts his feet up an motions Hoke to sit.
Name your salary.
Dat what she say.
Well, how does $65 a week sound?
Sound pretty good. ‘Course seventy- five sounds better.
So it does. Beginning this week.
Das mighty nice of you, Mist' Werthan. I 'preciate it. Mist' Werthan, you ever had people fightin’ over you?
No.
Well, I tell you. It feel good. He smiles and walks happily out of the office.

Only addition to the scene is a bulky console b/w TELEVIS set, which is ON at the moment, a soap opera in progress. Idella and Hoke are watching avidly. Idella is shelling p a paper bag for the pods and a bowl for the peas. She loo very old and frail. Daisy stops in the doorway.
I don't know how y'all can look at that.  78.
you see it a few times, you get in t.
Your brains are gonna dry up. I'll be up in my room reading. Don't make a mess with those peas, Idella.
Do I ever? Daisy goes upstairs. The two watch.
Ain't the blonde one got a lotta hair? How do she make it so shiny?
(shelling away) Washes it in my-naise. He looks dubious.
Yes she do. Had about it in Life Magazine. : “HOKE Don' seem human, do it?
Two young women drinking coffee in a kitchen.
Virginia, I saw Richard last night. Ominous organ MUSIC.
It looked to me like he was on his way to Hope's house! More ominous MUSIC.
Look out! Linda up to somethin’ now. What you think, Idella? No answer.  79.
Idella? 0.S. SOUND of BOWL hitting the floor. We ‘SEE the bowl overturned and peas rolling out on the Oriental rug.
Idella! Idella!

location: AUBURN AVENUE BAPTIST CHURCH / THE SANCTUARY

text: This is a fairly small church, humble in contrast to Dais Temple we have seen earlier. The sanctuary is about half- filled at the moment. A funeral is in progress. A BLACK CHOIR MEMBER - A TEEN-AGED GIRL, with a particula strong voice, is singing "What a Friend we Have in Jesus. She wears a choir robe. She is standing with the rest of choir, but this is the solo part of the service. A MINISTER, also black and also robed, stands nearby, jus behind a simple coffin. A SHOT OF THE SANCTUARY reveals that the entire populatio black, except for three white people in the rear -- Daisy Boolie and Florine. Hoke is sitting in the pew with them, the aisle, next to Boolie. Everyone in the congregation h a printed program of events. ON THE THREE WHITE FACES, a part of the service, but not part. Florine wears a stylish suit, Daisy has on a black with a veil. She looks straight ahead at the singer, her showing no emotion. Only Hoke's face expresses his feelin as the four watch the solemn proceedings.

For the first time, the kitchen looks a bit out of date, shabby. The linoleum is clean, but a little chipped and scruffy. An electric fry pan sits on one of the counters, . Clearly a concession to Boolie because it is shiny new ebviously never used. - Daisy is frying chicken in a large black cast iron skille The cut-up chicken is on the counter as is the paper bag of flour. She shakes the chicken in the bag, then places in the hot oil skillet. Hoke appears behind her, watching critically. Eventually cannot contain himself and speaks.  80.
You fixin' to ruin it.
What are you talking about?
You got de skillet turn up too high and de chicken too close together.
Mind your business.
It's yo' chicken. He shrugs, walks out of the kitchen. Daisy considers a Moment, turns the flame down.

Some time later. Daisy, wearing gardening gloves, is stan on a small kitchen stepladder, wielding a large pair of shears, trimming a shrub. Hoke stands at the foot of: the ladder, picking up the clippings and putting them in a ne wheelbarrow.
ESTABLISHING SHOT of ice storm in progress, branches weig down, icicles hanging everywhere, etc.
Effects of storm visible.

No furniture or decoration has changed here since we firs it, but everything is older. Daisy is on her knees rummag through the lowest commode drawer. Outside the storm is visible. The hall is dark. Daisy finds what she is lookin for, a stumpy old white candle. She shuts the drawer, get up, and we FOLLOW HER through THE DARK PANTRY into

somewhat lighter because of the windows. She lights the candle with kitchen matches, drips wax onto a saucer, and firms the candle in place. She heads back towards the liv room.  81. She walks through the dark HALL. We FOLLOW HER into

Only a little brighter, evidence of ice storm outside. Th room seems more cluttered, less organized than it was in And the darkness of the morning only accentuates the some shabby aura. Daisy goes to sit in her armchair. The current National Geographic is on the table. She picks it up and tries to read, but is unsuccessful in the poor light. Suddenly she HEARS the BACK DOOR open and close. FOOTSTEP She half-rises out of the chair in alarm.
Who is it?
Mornin', Miz Daisy.
Oh, Hoke. She sinks back into her chair with relief. Hoke comes int the doorway. She is carrying a paper bag, and wears an evercoat and galoshes. .
What in the world?

I learn to drive on ice when I deliver milk for the Avondale Dairy. Ain' much to it. I slip aroun' a little comin' down Briarcliff, but nothin' happen. Other folks bangin' into each other like they in the funny papers, tho'. Oh, I stop at” the 7-11. I figure yo' stove out and Lawd knows you got to have yo’ coffee in the morning. She is touched.
How sweet of you, Hoke! He hands her a cardboard cup and sips his own.
We ain' had no good coffee 'roun heah since Idella pass.  82.
Mmm Hmm. iI can fix her biscuits and we both know how to make her fried chicken. But nobody can make Idella's coffee. I wonder how she did it.
I doan' nome. They sip silently for a moment, deep in thoughts. Then:
Idella was lucky.
Yassum. I ‘spec she was. He starts out of the room.
Where are you going?
Put desheah things up. Take off my overshoes.
I didn't think you'd come today.
What you mean? It ain' my day off, is it? :
Boolie called and said he couldn't even get down his driveway. Well, I don't know what you can do around here except keep me company.
I see can I light us a fire. He leaves the room. The next few exchanges are Daisy call to him in the kitchen.
Eat anything you want out of the ice box. It'll all spoil anyway.
Yassum.
And wipe up what you tracked onto my kitchen floor.  83.

Now, Miz Daisy, what you think I am? A mess? This is an old routine between them and not without affec Daisy smiles. The PHONE RINGS, loudly. An intrusion on th ntimacy. Daisy gets up to answer. She speaks as she goes to the ha
Yes. That's exactly what I think you are.
All right den. All right.

(NOTE: The scene of following phone conversation shifts between Daisy's hall and BOOLIE'S DEN, where he sits wear cashmere sweater and a muffler. Florine can also be seen, wearing a full-length mink coat and expensive leather glo
Hello?
It'll all be melted by this afternoon. They said so on the radio. I'll be out after you as soon as I can get down the driveway.
Stay where you are, Boolie. Hoke is here with me.
How in the hell did he manage that?
He's very handy. I'm fine. I don't need a thing in the world.
Hello? (to Florine) I must have the wrong number. I never heard Mama say loving things about Hoke before.
I didn't say I love him. I said he was handy.  84.
(winking at Florine) Uh huh.
Honestly, Boolie. Are you trying to irritate me in the middle of an ice storm? She hangs up sharply. ON BOOLIE as he hangs up the phone, smiling at his wife.

A traffic jam is in progress. Cars standing still, HORNS BLARING, irritability in the air. It is early fall, but h and humid. One of the cars in the stalled lane is Daisy's. It's a ca haven't seen before -- a Cadillac sedan (circa 1960). All Daisy's cars, subsequent to the first Cadillac, are virtu the same -- all "Cadillac blue" -- but, of course, Boolie trades them in every two or three years -- a matter of eq At the moment Daisy is alone in her car, fanning herself her handkerchief, and out of sorts.
